instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0A
threads.message:
Board from other shop.
I See U700, <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> has been replaced.

L7030 0V on both sides.
F7000 0V on both sides - no short to ground.
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5V

Any idea where to start?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0A
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> first.
Next, all (4) LDO outputs for <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Be aware, 1V1 only appears when charger is connected to corresponding port.

You can compare diode mode readings between both chips; on LDO rails...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at 3.40V

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>LDO_3V3</SIGNAL> at 3.36V
<SIGNAL>LDO_1V8A</SIGNAL> at 1.81V 
<SIGNAL>LDO_1V8D</SIGNAL> at 1.8V
<SIGNAL>LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> at 0.0V

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>LDO_3V3</SIGNAL> at 3.36V
<SIGNAL>LDO_1V8A</SIGNAL> at 1.80V
<SIGNAL>LDO_1V8D</SIGNAL> at 1.8V
<SIGNAL>LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> at 0.05V

Diode mode the same on both chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0A
threads.message:
You may have to change both.
The problem is to get good chips for sure.

I've got more than 10 fake chips on Aliexpress, from various sellers.
I recently bought 5 "board wings" (10 chips), but didn't test any yet.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0A
threads.message:
Replaced both with chips from China, no luck and two from donor boards - same issue and same voltages.

I see <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> has been replaced as well - did that matter if its charge only 5V?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0A
threads.message:
This board can be a nightmare, if they screwed it up in the other service.
You may earn just a wasting time...
